stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes and largely completes a new “soap bar” gameplay object (rideable like a Koopa shell, time-limited, with bubble particle trail), then begins planning/experimenting with an “oil slick” that the soap cleans via dynamic texture/alpha changes. In parallel, he revisits the planned star-select UI redesign based on tiny per-course panoramas (from Biobak’s concept) and weighs ROM-space/performance tradeoffs of 2D images vs pre-rendered 3D scenes.
stream_context.significance_reason: A substantial new interactable mechanic is implemented end-to-end in a single stream (soap bar behavior + custom bubble particle effect), and the next linked mechanic (oil slick cleanup) is scoped with concrete technical approaches and constraints.

findings.summary: Kaze considers adding overworld-style water level manipulation over time, because the overworld is an island you rescue, so water returning gradually would fit the narrative structure.

A new “soap bar” object is designed as a rideable platform/vehicle: Mario can stand on it and ride it like a Koopa shell, but it only lasts briefly and disappears to prevent players from using it everywhere in the level.
He debates how to communicate that the soap is collectible/important, noting sparkles are a common SM64 affordance (like Koopa shells) but he is not fully sold on the look of sparkles.

He reuses and adapts an existing SM64-style action state/behavior (the Koopa shell riding action) for the soap bar, discovering there is a dedicated interaction type/pointer for rideable objects that he hadn’t realized existed.

He identifies a key bug source while debugging object position/offset issues: a debug change that synced camera movement to Mario’s update prevented manual position changes from taking effect as expected; removing it restores proper behavior.
He worries about a state carryover edge case: if the player exits a course while riding the soap bar, the “riding” state might persist into other contexts unless explicitly cleared.

Kaze implements a bubble trail using his own particle system, stating the original SM64 particle system is inefficient because it reloads textures repeatedly (making even ~10 bubbles expensive), whereas his system can handle “tons of bubbles.”

He attempts a bubble visual treatment that fades toward white using N64 color-combiner features (set-nth-color). This is complicated by the fact that nthcolor is disabled in his repo due to fuzz64 compatibility, requiring alternate color setup.

He tunes bubble spawn counts, layering, transparency, and floor-intersection issues (some bubbles appearing to sink into the floor), ultimately changing the spawn progression logic to ensure consistent emission rather than exhausting a fixed total prematurely.

The star select screen is being redesigned: each course will be represented by a very small panorama/scene conveying the course’s “vibe,” based on a concept from Biobak. Kaze dislikes his current implementation and prefers Biobak’s direction.

Kaze argues against using per-course 2D prerendered images for star-select backgrounds due to ROM space and emulator appearance: at 320x240 each could be ~0.3–0.5MB per course and would look like an un-upscaled blurry image; he prefers a pre-rendered 3D scene/model approach as cheaper and sharper in emulators.
He notes a concrete ROM-space win: removing the original Mario Kart 64 background assets saved about 0.3MB (he cites “just for the grass / two different grass planes”).
He mentions performance/visual tradeoffs with fog, stating orange fog significantly worsens performance but removing it would hurt visuals.

Over the week, he fixed all bugs found in OnlyUp64 and added movement improvements: ledge grabbing now works, and he changed wall interactions so walls that previously rejected jumps can now be jumped/kicked up consistently (a behavior he says SM64 didn’t allow).

He scopes the next mechanic: an “oil puddle/slick” that the soap cleans. The practical plan is to use a small texture format (IA-16/grayscale) and dynamically erase/modify alpha and pixel colors along Mario’s path so it looks like the puddle is being cleaned.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides the preferred concept direction for the new star-select UI: small per-level panorama scenes that capture each course’s vibe; Kaze explicitly shows Biobak’s mock/idea as working better than his own.
Biobak requests a bubble effect that fades toward white over time; Kaze attempts to reproduce this using N64 color-combiner techniques.
At the end, Kaze asks Biobak for a direct quality check on the oil slick look; Biobak responds positively (“Looks fantastic”), influencing Kaze to stop for the day satisfied with the direction.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears briefly mid-stream while at work; the interaction is mostly playful banter (microwaves/number systems) rather than production decisions.

findings.summary: Lilaa (via chat prompt) pushes Kaze to consider simpler solutions like modeling the puddles instead of dynamic cleanup; Kaze rejects it because the mesh would need to change dynamically and he wants the cleanup to visibly alter the puddle over time.
A viewer claims a similar idea was proposed earlier; Kaze dismisses concern by noting he hadn’t seen it, framing parallel invention as acceptable in his process.

key_stories.title: Building a rideable soap-bar mechanic with a custom bubble trail
key_stories.summary: Kaze designs a soap bar that Mario can ride like a Koopa shell, but that shrinks/disappears to limit how long players can exploit it. He iterates on collisions, riding behavior, and a bubble trail effect using his custom particle engine, dealing with multiple bugs around offsets, action states, and spawning consistency.
key_stories.challenge: Create a new interactable that reads clearly, feels good to ride, and can be implemented within SM64’s behavior/action framework without introducing state bugs.
key_stories.process: Reuses the shell-riding action/interaction type, adjusts collision to allow mounting from sides, debugs offset/state issues (including a camera-sync debug change), then builds and tunes a bubble particle effect (layering, alpha, spawn logic) and attempts a fade-to-white look.
key_stories.outcome: Soap-bar behavior and bubble trail reach a satisfactory state by end of stream; Kaze identifies remaining edge case risk (exiting a course while riding) and queues the next connected mechanic (oil slick).
key_stories.key_quote: We programmed the whole soap bar just today—that's not that bad, with a pretty sick effect.

key_stories.title: Star-select redesign constrained by N64 ROM space and emulator presentation
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains a new star-select concept: each course gets a tiny panorama depicting its vibe. He rejects a straightforward 2D-image approach due to ROM size and blur on emulators, preferring a 3D scene/panorama approach that can look sharper and cost less space.
key_stories.challenge: Make a modern-feeling star-select UI that communicates level identity while staying within strict ROM and rendering constraints.
key_stories.process: Reviews his prototype, compares it to Biobak’s mock/concept, estimates ROM costs for 320x240 per-course images, and references previous ROM savings from removing unused backgrounds.
key_stories.outcome: Direction aligns with Biobak’s panorama concept; technical implementation remains in progress with ROM-space strategy guiding decisions.

key_stories.title: Harassment incident during development
key_stories.summary: Kaze briefly shares receiving a rape threat as a male creator—new to him compared to common death threats—then speculates it may have come from a young, overly invested viewer reacting to his comments about philosophy. The moment highlights the psychological background noise of shipping a high-profile fan project in public.
key_stories.challenge: Managing emotional impact and safety concerns while maintaining creative momentum and public presence.
key_stories.process: Acknowledges the message, contextualizes it as unusual, and moves back to development work.
key_stories.outcome: No immediate action is discussed on-stream, but it’s a clear point for interview exploration about moderation, boundaries, and support systems.
key_stories.key_quote: I as a male have gotten a rape threat. That's insane. That's never happened to me before.

open_questions.topic: Soap bar state persistence across course transitions
open_questions.context: Kaze expresses a fear that exiting a course while riding the soap bar could cause the riding state to carry over improperly.
questions: Did this edge case actually occur in testing later? If so, what was the fix (explicit state reset on level exit, clearing ridden object pointers, etc.)?
How do you generally prevent ‘Mario action state’ bugs from leaking between custom mechanics in decomp? Do you have a checklist for teardown/reset?
Did this concern influence later design decisions (e.g., where soap appears, how long it lasts, restrictions on use near exits/warps)?

open_questions.topic: Final implementation plan for the panorama-based star select
open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak are iterating on a new star select where each level has a miniature panorama, but Kaze is dissatisfied with his current attempt and is weighing 2D vs 3D approaches due to ROM space and emulator appearance.
questions: What did the final star-select implementation become: real-time 3D mini-scenes, static pre-rendered images, or a hybrid?
How many courses/panoramas were budgeted, and what was the final ROM-space cost per course?
What tools/pipeline did you settle on (Fast64 export, custom compression, bespoke scene format), and what were the biggest technical blockers?
Did you define an art ‘style rule’ for these panoramas so they stay consistent across the hack?

open_questions.topic: fuzz64 constraints disabling nthcolor and how that shapes visuals
open_questions.context: Kaze notes nthcolor is disabled in his repo because of fuzz64, complicating a bubble fade-to-white effect and requiring alternative combiner setup.
questions: Why exactly was nthcolor disabled—what does fuzz64 break or misinterpret?
How often do emulator/toolchain compatibility issues (fuzz64, PJ64, etc.) dictate art/graphics decisions in RTYI?
Do you maintain a compatibility matrix for emulators/hardware, and what is the target for release (console-first vs emulator-first)?

open_questions.topic: Oil slick cleanup mechanic: dynamic texture editing on N64
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes cleaning oil by dynamically erasing/altering alpha and pixel colors along Mario’s path using a small texture format (IA-16), but notes shine/reflectivity is hard without more complex tricks.
questions: Did the oil slick ship as dynamic texture erasure, vertex-color tricks, a deforming mesh, or something else?
What were the performance costs (CPU time, RDP/RSP load, texture uploads) of updating the mask/texture in real time?
How did you decide between ‘realistic’ black oil, rainbow iridescence, or a stylized look? Was there a reference or an in-game readability reason?
How did you author/quantize the mask so it didn’t look jagged at N64 resolutions?

open_questions.topic: Unnamed ‘really useful tool’ from ~20 years ago being remade
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions (but refuses to name) a developer of a very useful SM64-related tool writing him that they’re making a new one.
questions: What tool was this (e.g., level editor, asset pipeline, debugger), and how did it affect your workflow on RTYI?
Why couldn’t you talk about it on stream—was it privacy, NDA, or just not ready to announce?
Did the new tool eventually change how the team collaborated (e.g., faster iteration, fewer custom scripts)?
